photo.description: The Gallery of 1812 in the Hermitage (Saint Petersburg, Russia) was created in commemoration of Russia's victory over Napoleon. Its walls bear 332 portraits of Russian generals who participated in the campaigns of 1812-1815. The portraits were created by the English artist George Dawe and the architects of the gallery are Carlo Rossi and Vasily Stasov. You will find this gallery in hall 197 in the Hermitage.

photo.description: The State Hermitage (Russian: Госуда́рственный Эрмита́ж; IPA: [gəsʊˈdarstvʲɪnɨj ɪrmʲɪˈtaʂ]) is a museum of art and culture in Saint Petersburg, Russia. One of the largest and oldest museums of the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great and has been open to the public since 1852. Its collections, of which only a small part is on permanent display, comprise nearly 3 million items, including the largest collection of paintings in the world.

photo.description: The Neva (Russian: Нева́, IPA: [nʲɪˈva]) is a river in northwestern Russia flowing from Lake Ladoga through the western part of Leningrad Oblast (historical region of Ingria) to the Neva Bay of the Gulf of Finland. Despite its modest length (74 km), it is the third largest river in Europe in terms of average discharge (after the Volga and the Danube). The Neva is the only river flowing from Lake Ladoga. It flows through the city Saint Petersburg, three smaller towns of Shlisselburg, Kirovsk and Otradnoye, and dozens of settlements. The river is navigable throughout and is part of the Volga–Baltic Waterway and White Sea – Baltic Canal. It is a site of numerous major historical events, including the Battle of the Neva in 1240 which gave Alexander Nevsky his name, the founding of Saint Petersburg in 1703, and the Siege of Leningrad by the German army during World War II.
photo.title: 2012-04 St Petersburg 034

photo.description: The State Hermitage Museum (Russian: Государственный Эрмитаж / Gosudarstvenniy Ermitaž) in Saint Petersburg, Russia is one of the largest, oldest, most important and famous art galleries and museums of human history and culture in the world. The vast Hermitage collections are displayed in six buildings, the main one being the Winter Palace which used to be the official residence of the Russian Tsars. The Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg, Russia.

photo.description: The State Hermitage is a museum of art and culture situated in Saint Petersburg, Russia. One of the largest and oldest museums of the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great and open to the public since 1852. Its collections, of which only a small part is on permanent display, comprise nearly 3 million items, including the largest collection of paintings in the world. The collections occupy a large complex of six historic buildings along Palace Embankment, including the Winter Palace, a former residence of Russian emperors. Apart from them, the Menshikov Palace, Museum of Porcelain, Storage Facility at Staraya Derevnya and the eastern wing of the General Staff Building also make part of the museum.

One of the largest and oldest museums of the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great and open to the public since 1852. Its collections, of which only a small part is on permanent display, comprise nearly 3 million items, including the largest collection of paintings in the world. The collections occupy a large complex of six historic buildings along Palace Embankment, including the Winter Palace, a former residence of Russian emperors. Apart from them, the Menshikov Palace, Museum of Porcelain, Storage Facility at Staraya Derevnya and the eastern wing of the General Staff Building also make part of the museum.

Apart from them, the Menshikov Palace, Museum of Porcelain, Storage Facility at Staraya Derevnya and the eastern wing of the General Staff Building also make part of the museum.
photo.title: Hermitage Museum

photo.description: The queue to get into the Hermitage. It took about 30 minutes to go from Dvortsovaya Ploschad into the courtyard (where this photo was taken), and another 30 minutes to get inside from the courtyard, and then about 10 minutes still until we were past the gates. In all, I got the feeling that was a "good" day.

photo.description: There are museums and museums... but the Hermitage in Saint Petersburg is more than that. I couldn't find the right words for my visits to the Hermitage last days. It's to much, but I think it's a magic combination of architecture, enormous amount of art, the stories (history) behind the Hermitage and the people who work there. I saw a small piece of the total Hermitage and the collection. I hope I get the opportunity for more visits later. On the photo above you see the Main Staircase of the Hermitage. The architects of this staircase are Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli and Vasily Stasov.
photo.tags: russia saintpetersburg hermitage museum themainstaircase francescobartolomeorastrelli vasilystasov санктпетербург
photo.title: The Main Staircase of the Winter Palace

photo.description: An incredible museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. As with everything in Russia, it's oversized, ornate, impressive.. they almost scream at you "HEY! LOOKIT ME! I'M ENORMOUS!"
photo.title: Hermitage Museum Entry

photo.description: Philip the Arab (Latin: Marcus Julius Philippus Augustus;[1] c. 204 – 249), also known as Philip or Philippus Arabs, was Roman Emperor from 244 to 249. He came from Syria, and rose to become a major figure in the Roman Empire. He achieved power after the death of Gordian III, quickly negotiating peace with the Sassanid Empire. During his reign, Rome celebrated its millennium. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_the_Arab
photo.title: Philip the Arab

photo.description: The State Hermitage (Russian: Госуда́рственный Эрмита́ж; IPA: [gəsʊˈdarstvʲɪnɨj ɪrmʲɪˈtaʂ]) is a museum of art and culture in Saint Petersburg, Russia. One of the largest and oldest museums of the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great and has been open to the public since 1852. Its collections, of which only a small part is on permanent display, comprise nearly 3 million items, including the largest collection of paintings in the world.
photo.title: 2012-04 St Petersburg 020

photo.description: Roman Emperor from 244 -249 AD- by the standards of the 3rd Century a long reign. He celebrated the 100th anniversary of Rome's founding in 248, but was deposed by a military coup the following year. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_the_Arab From the Hermitage Museum This is what Gibbon, politically correct as always, has to say about him: "Philip ....was an Arab by birth, and consequently, in the earlier part of his life, a robber by profession. His rise from so obscure a station to the first dignities of the empire, seems to prove that he was a bold and able leader. But his boldness prompted him to aspire to the throne, and his abilities were employed to supplant, not to serve, his indulgent master. The minds of the soldiers were irritated by an artificial scarcity, created by his contrivance in the camp; and the distress of the army was attributed to the youth and incapacity of the prince. It is not in our power to trace the successive steps of the secret conspiracy and open sedition, which were at length fatal to Gordian. Murder of Gordian A.D. 244, March A sepulchral monument was erected to his memory on the spot where he was killed, near the conflux of the Euphrates with the little river Aboras. The fortunate Philip, raised to the empire by the votes of the soldiers, found a ready obedience from the senate and the provinces. " www.ccel.org/ccel/gibbon/decline/files/volume1/chap7.htm#RGN
photo.tags: roman fisheye hermitage hermitagemuseum saintpetersburg russia sculpture toyfisheye
photo.title: Philip the Arab

photo.description: The Peacock Clock in the Pavillion Hall of the Small Hermitage. It also includes the figures of a cockerel and owl. All three of the birds move. A gift to Catherine II from her lover Grigory Potiomkin. It was made by celebrated goldsmith and clockmaker James Cox.
photo.title: Peacock Clock

photo.title: img_1691

photo.description: www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/08/hm89_0_1_35.html The Peter the Great (Small Throne) Room was created in 1833 by Auguste Montferrand and restored after the 1837 fire by Vasily Stasov. The room is dedicated to the memory of Peter the Great - its decoration features the Emperor's monogram (two Latin letters P), double-headed eagles and crowns. In a niche that is designed like a triumphal arch is a painting of Peter I with Minerva. Set into the upper parts of the walls are paintings (by Pietro Scotti and Barnaba Medici) depicting Peter in major battles of the Northern War. The throne was made in St Petersburg in the late 18th century. The room is embellished with panels of Lyons velvet embroidered with silver thread and silver articles by St Petersburg craftsmen.
photo.title: "Small Throne Room"
